ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned so much Yiddish! If I compare this to other language classes I have taken before, this one taught me so much more. I was so impressed that we made it through present and past tense, along with learning a decent amount of vocab *and* history of the language and culture.
I developed basic Yiddish proficiency including but not limited to: basic conversational skills, verb conjugation, past tense, and adjectives.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Josh is the biggest strength -- his commitment to the course is palpable and impressive and you really feel like he wants you to improve over the course of the semester. I thought it was organized well and I felt like it was easy to keep up with the pace as long as you show up to class regularly. The only weakness is the quantity of homework some days, but he tries to balance it out.

Very well organized. Not a lot, if any memorization. The learning of new vocab and syntactic structures feels natural. Very creative assignments. There's a lot of homework. If we could drop a couple of homeworks a semester that would be nice.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: YES! TAKE YIDDISH! Especially as a Jewish student, this course was incredibly meaningful in addition to being intellectually gratifying. In general, it's like taking a language class plus getting a really good cultural background for Ashkenazi Jewry. I definitely think people who are looking to start a language for the distributional requirements should strongly consider taking it, but also I didn't even need the credit and I'm so glad I took the course anyway!! It was a fun challenge that didn't have to do with the other classes I was taking. (Although, as a history major, much of it felt quite relevant and fun.)
